trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Authentication Libraries | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Authentication Libraries | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: The Azure AD Authentication Library (ADAL) allows client application developers to easily authenticate users to cloud or on-premises Active Directory (AD) and then obtain access tokens for securing API calls.
trans-unit.target: The Azure AD Authentication Library (ADAL) allows client application developers to easily authenticate users to cloud or on-premises Active Directory (AD) and then obtain access tokens for securing API calls.

trans-unit.source: The Azure AD authentication Library (ADAL) enables client application developers to easily authenticate users to cloud or on-premises Active Directory (AD), and then obtain access tokens for securing API calls.
trans-unit.target: The Azure AD authentication Library (ADAL) enables client application developers to easily authenticate users to cloud or on-premises Active Directory (AD), and then obtain access tokens for securing API calls.

trans-unit.source: ADAL has many features that make authentication easier for developers, such as asynchronous support, a configurable token cache that stores access tokens and refresh tokens, automatic token refresh when an access token expires and a refresh token is available, and more.
trans-unit.target: ADAL has many features that make authentication easier for developers, such as asynchronous support, a configurable token cache that stores access tokens and refresh tokens, automatic token refresh when an access token expires and a refresh token is available, and more.

trans-unit.source: By handling most of the complexity, ADAL can help a developer focus on business logic in their application and easily secure resources without being an expert on security.
trans-unit.target: By handling most of the complexity, ADAL can help a developer focus on business logic in their application and easily secure resources without being an expert on security.

trans-unit.source: ADAL is available on a variety of platforms.
trans-unit.target: ADAL is available on a variety of platforms.

trans-unit.source: Active Directory Authentication Library (ADAL) for JavaScript
trans-unit.target: Active Directory Authentication Library (ADAL) for JavaScript

trans-unit.target: Active Directory Authentication Library (ADAL) for Objective-C

trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Passport for Node.js (npm)

trans-unit.target: Active Directory Authentication Library (ADAL) for Java

trans-unit.target: Identity Protocol Extensions for the Microsoft .NET Framework 4.5

trans-unit.target: Azure AD identity model extensions for .NET (Github)

trans-unit.target: JSON Web Token Handler For the Microsoft .Net Framework 4.5

trans-unit.target: Azure AD identity model extensions for .NET (Github)

trans-unit.source: OWIN middleware that enables an application to use Microsoft's technology for authentication.
trans-unit.target: OWIN middleware that enables an application to use Microsoft's technology for authentication.

trans-unit.source: OWIN middleware that enables an application to use OpenIDConnect for authentication.
trans-unit.target: OWIN middleware that enables an application to use OpenIDConnect for authentication.

trans-unit.source: OWIN middleware that enables an application to use WS-Federation for authentication.
trans-unit.target: OWIN middleware that enables an application to use WS-Federation for authentication.

trans-unit.source: Here are three common scenarios in which ADAL can be used for authentication.
trans-unit.target: Here are three common scenarios in which ADAL can be used for authentication.

trans-unit.source: Authenticating Users of a Client Application to a Remote Resource
trans-unit.target: Authenticating Users of a Client Application to a Remote Resource

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, a developer has a client, such as a WPF application, that needs to access a remote resource secured by Azure AD, such as a web API.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, a developer has a client, such as a WPF application, that needs to access a remote resource secured by Azure AD, such as a web API.

trans-unit.source: He has an Azure subscription, knows how to invoke the downstream web API, and knows the Azure AD tenant that the web API uses.
trans-unit.target: He has an Azure subscription, knows how to invoke the downstream web API, and knows the Azure AD tenant that the web API uses.

trans-unit.source: As a result, he can use ADAL to facilitate authentication with Azure AD, either by fully delegating the authentication experience to ADAL or by explicitly handling user credentials.
trans-unit.target: As a result, he can use ADAL to facilitate authentication with Azure AD, either by fully delegating the authentication experience to ADAL or by explicitly handling user credentials.

trans-unit.source: ADAL makes it easy to authenticate the user, obtain an access token and refresh token from Azure AD, and then use the access token to make requests to the web API.
trans-unit.target: ADAL makes it easy to authenticate the user, obtain an access token and refresh token from Azure AD, and then use the access token to make requests to the web API.

trans-unit.source: For a code sample that demonstrates this scenario using authentication to Azure AD, see [Native Client WPF Application to Web API](https://github.com/azureadsamples/nativeclient-dotnet).
trans-unit.target: For a code sample that demonstrates this scenario using authentication to Azure AD, see [Native Client WPF Application to Web API](https://github.com/azureadsamples/nativeclient-dotnet).

trans-unit.source: Authenticating a Server Application to a Remote Resource
trans-unit.target: Authenticating a Server Application to a Remote Resource

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, a developer has an application running on a server that needs to access a remote resource secured by Azure AD, such as a web API.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, a developer has an application running on a server that needs to access a remote resource secured by Azure AD, such as a web API.

trans-unit.source: He has an Azure subscription, knows how to invoke the downstream service, and knows the Azure AD tenant the web API uses.
trans-unit.target: He has an Azure subscription, knows how to invoke the downstream service, and knows the Azure AD tenant the web API uses.

trans-unit.source: As a result, he can use ADAL to facilitate authentication with Azure AD by explicitly handling the application’s credentials.
trans-unit.target: As a result, he can use ADAL to facilitate authentication with Azure AD by explicitly handling the application’s credentials.

trans-unit.source: ADAL makes it easy to retrieve a token from Azure AD by using the application’s client credential and then use that token to make requests to the web API.
trans-unit.target: ADAL makes it easy to retrieve a token from Azure AD by using the application’s client credential and then use that token to make requests to the web API.

trans-unit.source: ADAL also handles managing the lifetime of the access token by caching it and renewing it as necessary.
trans-unit.target: ADAL also handles managing the lifetime of the access token by caching it and renewing it as necessary.

trans-unit.source: For a code sample that demonstrates this scenario, see [Console Application to Web API](https://github.com/AzureADSamples/Daemon-DotNet).
trans-unit.target: For a code sample that demonstrates this scenario, see [Console Application to Web API](https://github.com/AzureADSamples/Daemon-DotNet).

trans-unit.source: Authenticating a Server Application on Behalf of a User to Access a Remote Resource
trans-unit.target: Authenticating a Server Application on Behalf of a User to Access a Remote Resource

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, a developer has an application running on a server that needs to access a remote resource secured by Azure AD, such as a web API.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, a developer has an application running on a server that needs to access a remote resource secured by Azure AD, such as a web API.

trans-unit.source: The request also needs to be made on behalf of a user in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: The request also needs to be made on behalf of a user in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: He has an Azure subscription, knows how to invoke the downstream web API, and knows the Azure AD tenant the service uses.
trans-unit.target: He has an Azure subscription, knows how to invoke the downstream web API, and knows the Azure AD tenant the service uses.

trans-unit.source: Once the user is authenticated to the web application, the application can get an authorization code for the user from Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Once the user is authenticated to the web application, the application can get an authorization code for the user from Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: The web application can then use ADAL to obtain an access token and refresh token on behalf of a user using the authorization code and client credentials associated with the application from Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: The web application can then use ADAL to obtain an access token and refresh token on behalf of a user using the authorization code and client credentials associated with the application from Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Once the web application is in possession of the access token, it can call the web API until the token expires.
trans-unit.target: Once the web application is in possession of the access token, it can call the web API until the token expires.

trans-unit.source: When the token expires, the web application can use ADAL to get a new access token by using the refresh token that was previously received.
trans-unit.target: When the token expires, the web application can use ADAL to get a new access token by using the refresh token that was previously received.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Active Directory developer's guide
trans-unit.target: The Azure Active Directory developer's guide

trans-unit.target: Authentication scenarios for Azure Active directory
